profileText: (Father of Charles Jared Ingersoll and Joseph Reed Ingersoll), a Delegate from Pennsylvania; born in New Haven, Conn., October 24, 1749; received a classical education; was graduated from Yale College in 1766; settled in Philadelphia, Pa., in 1771; studied law and was admitted to the bar in 1773; finished his legal education at the Middle Temple, London, England, in 1774, and then went to Paris in 1776; returned to Philadelphia in 1778 and commenced practice; Member of the Continental Congress in 1780; delegate to the convention that framed the Federal Constitution in 1787 and signed it; was the first attorney general of Pennsylvania 1790-1799 and served again from 1811 to 1817; United States district attorney for the eastern district of Pennsylvania; declined the appointment of judge of the Federal court in 1801; unsuccessful Federalist candidate for Vice President of the United States in 1812; presiding judge of the district court of Philadelphia County until his death in Philadelphia, Pa., October 31, 1822; interment in the First Presbyterian Church Cemetery, Fourth and Pine Streets.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Gipson, Lawrence H. American Loyalist, Jared Ingersoll. New Haven, Conn.: Yale University Press, 1971; Ingersoll, Jared. Jared Ingersoll Papers. Edited by Franklin B. Dexter. New Haven, 1918.
------. Jared Ingersoll: A Study of American Loyalism in Relation to British Colonial Government. Russell & Russell Publishers, 1969.
Ingersoll, Jared. Jared Ingersoll Papers. Edited by Franklin B. Dexter. New Haven, 1918.

researchRecord.description: Includes letters and portraits of prominent Americans, including Jared Ingersoll.

researchRecord.name: Letter, March 27, 1815, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: Ingersoll writes to Joseph Highee regarding the sale of lands owned by them in western New York.

researchRecord.name: In the papers of the Ingersoll family collection, 1797-1954, .2 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Consists chiefly of letters of Jared Ingersoll to his son Charles while he was a student at the College of New Jersey (now Princeton University).
